data.question: What is the title of the article?
data.answer: Turn-On Fluorescence Sensing of Nucleoside Polyphosphates Using a Xanthene-Based Zn(II) Complex Chemosensor

data.question: Who are the authors of the article?
data.answer: Akio Ojida, Ippei Takashima, Takahiro Kohira, Hiroshi Nonaka, and Itaru Hamachi

data.question: What is the main focus of the article?
data.answer: The article focuses on a new fluorescent chemosensor for nucleoside polyphosphates such as ATP using metal−anion coordination chemistry.

data.question: What is the binding affinity (Kapp) of the chemosensor 1−2Zn(II) for ATP?
True or False: The chemosensor 1−2Zn(II) can detect nucleoside polyphosphates with a fluorescence enhancement (F/Fo > 15).
What mechanism is the 'turn-on' fluorescence of 1−2Zn(II) based on?
data.answer: The 'turn-on' fluorescence of 1−2Zn(II) is based on a mechanism that involves the binding-induced recovery of the conjugated form of the xanthene ring from its nonfluorescent deconjugated state.

data.question: True or False: The chemosensor 1−2Zn(II) shows a large fluorescence enhancement upon binding to ATP under neutral aqueous conditions.
What is the fluorescence intensity increase ratio upon addition of 10 μM ATP to the chemosensor 1−2Zn(II)?
True or False: The chemosensor 1−2Zn(II) has a strong binding affinity for monophosphorylated species such as AMP.
What is the role of the two Zn(II)−Dpa sites in the binding mechanism of 1−2Zn(II) with nucleoside polyphosphates?
data.answer: The two Zn(II)−Dpa sites interact with the β- and γ-phosphate groups of nucleoside polyphosphates, facilitating strong binding affinity.

data.question: True or False: The chemosensor 1−2Zn(II) can selectively sense nucleoside polyphosphates with high selectivity and strong binding affinity.
What is the fluorescence quantum yield of the binding complex of 1−2Zn(II) with ATP?
True or False: The chemosensor 1−2Zn(II) is applicable for fluorescence imaging of ATP particulate stores in living cells.
What is the synthetic precursor to the chemosensor 1−2Zn(II)?
data.answer: Compound 5 was converted to 7 by radical bromination with NBS, followed by nucleophilic substitution with 2,2′-dipicolylamine (Dpa) at both methyl groups.

data.question: True or False: The chemosensor 1−2Zn(II) shows a weak fluorescence emission in neutral aqueous conditions before binding to ATP.
What is the role of the μ-oxo−dizinc(II) core in the fluorescence mechanism of 1−2Zn(II)?
data.answer: ATP binding to the two Zn(II)−Dpa sites induces the disruption of the μ-oxo−dizinc(II) core, resulting in the recovery of the conjugated xanthene structure showing strong fluorescence emission.

data.question: True or False: The fluorescence intensity of the ATP binding complex of 1−2Zn(II) is unaffected by pH changes in the range from pH 6 to 9.
What modification was made to the chemosensor 1−2Zn(II) to increase its lipophilicity for cell membrane penetration?
data.answer: 1−2Zn(II) was modified by acetylation at both hydroxyl groups.

data.question: True or False: The chemosensor 1−2Zn(II) can visualize ATP stores inside living cells without being affected by pH changes.
What is the significance of the turn-on fluorescence sensing mechanism of 1−2Zn(II) for ATP?
data.answer: It demonstrates a new design principle for anion chemosensors and highlights the bioanalytical utility of 1−2Zn(II) as a molecular tool for fluorescence imaging of ATP stores in living cells.
